title-group.article-title: Addressing Bias in Preterm Birth Research: The Role of Advanced Imputation Techniques for Missing Race and Ethnicity in Perinatal Health Data

article-meta.aff: 1.Columbia University School of Nursing, New York, NY, United States
2.Data Science Institute, Columbia University, New York, NY, United States
3.Center for Home Care Policy & Research, VNS Health, New York, NY, United States
4.University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing, Philadelphia, PA, United States

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding Author: Jihye Kim Scroggins; 560 W 168th St, New York, NY 10032, USA; jks2238@cumc.columbia.edu

fn.p: Jihye Kim Scroggins contributed to the conceptualization, data analysis, and drafting the manuscript. Ismael Ibrahim Hulchafo contributed to the conceptualization and data analysis. Maxim Topaz contributed to the conceptualization and design. Kenrick Cato contributed to the conceptualization and design. Veronica Barcelona contributed to the conceptualization, design, and supervision of the project. All authors contributed to interpreting data and revising the manuscript.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Objectives:
sec.p: To evaluate the effectiveness of Bayesian Improved Surname Geocoding (BISG) and Bayesian Improved First Name Surname Geocoding (BIFSG) in estimating race and ethnicity, and how they influence odds ratios for preterm birth.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We analyzed hospital birth admission electronic health records (EHR) data (N=9,985). We created two simulation sets with 40% of race and ethnicity data missing randomly or more likely for non-Hispanic black birthing people who had preterm birth. We calculated C-statistics to evaluate how accurately BISG and BIFSG estimate race and ethnicity. We examined the association between race and ethnicity and preterm birth using logistic regression and reported odds ratios (OR).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: BISG and BIFSG showed high accuracy for most racial and ethnic categories (C-statistics=0.94-0.97, 95% confidence intervals [CI]=0.92-0.97). When race and ethnicity were not missing at random, BISG (OR=1.25, CI=0.97-1.62) and BIFSG (OR=1.38, CI=1.08-1.76) resulted in positive estimates mirroring the true association (OR=1.68, CI=1.34-2.09) for Non-Hispanic Black birthing people, while traditional methods showed contrasting estimates (Complete case OR=0.62, CI=0.41-0.94; multiple imputation OR=0.63, CI=0.40-0.98).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: BISG and BIFSG accurately estimate missing race and ethnicity in perinatal EHR data, decreasing bias in preterm birth research, and are recommended over traditional methods to reduce potential bias.
